As far as I can tell, the plan was just a (rather transparent) attempt to inflate equity markets. The drain in revenue would have moved SS's insolvency date up by about 4 years to 2013. 
 
 I will agree that it MAY have been a better plan to start with, but trying to institute it when he did, when we are just a few years from the SS crisis, was just foolish. Too little too late. Like everything else Bush has done, it was jsut not based in reality.
 
 Last year, The comptroller (walker) warned us that if we did not figure out a way to cut spending and cut our debt load that by 2040 the ENTIRE federal budget would be eaten up by JUST interest payments on that debt. He made some assumptions in making that prediction that have turned out to be incorrect. First, he assumed that Bush was going to do as he promised and continue to shrink the deficit. Instead we are looking at a $400 billion deficit for next year and then roughly the same for the 2 following years. With that extra 1.2 trillion in debt, that 2040 number moves up to 2028. He also based his calculations on current treasury yields without accounting for the fact that as our economic situation worsens treasury yields will have to increase. 
 
 At a 5% yield, that date moves up to 2020. At a 6.25% yield it moves up to 2018. 
 
 We just do not haev the money to be instituting changes such as Bush suggested to SS. It certainly would have been good in the long term, but there IS NO long term for SS. SS cannot possibly survive long enough for it to have made a difference.
